You only need to cut back on simple carbs, such as sugar, and processed foods made from white flour, rice, etc..  Simple carbs are the ones that spike your blood sugar, resulting in a corresponding insulin spike.Insulin is known as the fat storage hormone and whatever of those simple carbs that isn't used for energy right away is shuttled, by insulin, into fat cells.Make sure you eat plenty of complex carbs, such as those found in vegetables, whole grains, nuts, seeds, etc because those are the ones that take a long time to break down, keeping your blood sugar levels more stable.Check out low glycemic foods and center your meals around those.  If you do eat foods that spike your blood sugar, make sure you pair it with something that will slow its breakdown.
